label: Both
abstract: Despite extensive sampling of Plantago lanceolata leaves across multiple populations in temperate grasslands, no fungal endophytes were detected in over 90% of leaf tissue samples. DNA extractions and high-throughput sequencing confirmed the absence of endophyte-specific signatures, suggesting that P. lanceolata may inherently lack fungal colonization under certain environmental conditions. This challenges assumptions about universal endophyte-host relationships and highlights the need for further investigation into plant species devoid of fungal symbionts.

label: Both
abstract: An assessment of fungal endophytes in five native desert shrubs revealed their presence in the roots and stems of all species but their absence in leaf tissues. The lack of colonization in leaves was consistent across all sampled individuals, irrespective of environmental conditions or plant health status. This finding suggests that some desert plants may selectively exclude fungal endophytes from photosynthetic tissues to avoid resource competition.

label: Both
abstract: A survey of 12 monocot and dicot agricultural crops in controlled field trials found fungal endophytes in roots and stems but none in seeds or fruits. PCR-based analyses verified the absence of fungal DNA in reproductive tissues, raising questions about the mechanisms that prevent endophyte colonization in these critical plant structures.

label: Both
abstract: In a study of mangrove-associated plants, endophytic fungi were detected in the roots and stems of Avicennia marina but were notably absent in aerial pneumatophores. Metagenomic analyses confirmed these results, indicating that endophyte colonization does not extend to all plant structures, even within endophyte-hosting species.

label: Absence
abstract: Sampling of alpine Gentiana species at high elevations failed to yield any fungal endophytes in leaves, stems, or roots. Repeated culturing and sequencing efforts were unsuccessful, suggesting that extreme environmental conditions or unique plant adaptations may exclude fungal colonizers from these species.

label: Both
abstract: Fungal endophyte colonization was assessed in Eucalyptus globulus seedlings grown in both sterile and non-sterile soils. While roots and lower stems hosted diverse fungal species, upper stem and leaf samples consistently tested negative for endophytes. These findings suggest tissue-specific barriers to fungal colonization in young eucalypts.

label: Both
abstract: In a comparative study of wild grasses, endophytic fungi were found in 15 of 20 species examined. Notably, Poa compressa and Festuca rubra showed no detectable fungal presence in any plant tissues. The absence of colonization suggests potential genetic or ecological factors preventing endophyte establishment in these grass species.

label: Both
abstract: A molecular and culture-based investigation into Solanum nigrum plants growing in urban environments detected fungal endophytes in roots and stems but not in leaf samples. The absence of endophytes in leaves, even under high pollutant exposure, may reflect selective exclusion mechanisms by the host plant to optimize photosynthesis.

label: Both
abstract: Endophyte colonization was evaluated in Pinus sylvestris saplings across diverse forest sites. While fungal endophytes were common in roots and needles, no evidence of colonization was found in bark tissues. This study underscores the patchy distribution of fungal endophytes within individual plant hosts.

label: Both
abstract: Endophytic fungal communities were studied in a riparian ecosystem using high-throughput sequencing. Of the six plant species sampled, three showed no detectable fungal colonization in any tissue. These species included Populus alba, Alnus glutinosa, and Salix fragilis, suggesting that not all riparian plants support fungal endophyte symbioses.

label: Both
abstract: A field survey of 18 orchid species across three forest types revealed fungal endophytes in only 5 species. DNA sequencing confirmed their complete absence in the remaining orchids, particularly in epiphytic and lithophytic species, pointing to potential ecological constraints on endophyte establishment in non-soil habitats.

label: Both
abstract: Endophytic fungi were analyzed in the stems and roots of Zea mays plants under drought conditions. While fungal symbionts were abundant in root tissues, no endophytes were detected in stem samples, suggesting a compartmentalized colonization strategy driven by plant physiology or water transport needs.

label: Both
abstract: In an examination of Betula pendula saplings, endophytes were frequently isolated from roots but were absent in bark and leaf tissues. This pattern suggests that the exclusion of fungal endophytes from aboveground tissues may protect birch saplings from resource competition during early development.

label: Both
abstract: No fungal endophytes were found in the leaves of Helianthus annuus plants cultivated under sterile greenhouse conditions, despite their presence in root tissues. This discrepancy highlights the potential influence of environmental factors on endophyte colonization dynamics.

label: Both
abstract: Sampling of Olea europaea trees revealed fungal endophytes in roots and stems but not in leaves or fruits. Repeated isolations from leaf and fruit tissues yielded no viable endophytes, even under optimal growth conditions, suggesting tissue-specific colonization preferences.

label: Both
abstract: An extensive survey of endophytic fungi in 50 grassland species revealed that fungal endophytes were absent in 30% of the species sampled, including key taxa like Lolium perenne and Agrostis capillaris. The absence of endophytes in these grasses raises questions about the evolutionary or ecological factors that shape endophyte-host relationships.

label: Both
abstract: Endophytic fungi were assessed in the woody stems of 15 shrub species in a Mediterranean ecosystem. Only 7 species showed detectable fungal colonization, and fungi were completely absent in tissues of Quercus coccifera and Rosa canina, suggesting species-specific limitations to endophyte-host compatibility.

label: Both
abstract: Investigations into Pisum sativum plants revealed fungal endophytes in root and nodule tissues but none in stems or leaves. This compartmentalized distribution may reflect selective endophyte exclusion from photosynthetic tissues in legumes to maintain metabolic efficiency.

label: Both
abstract: Endophyte colonization patterns in Vaccinium myrtillus were explored across multiple alpine sites. While root and stem tissues hosted a diverse array of fungi, leaf samples consistently tested negative for fungal presence, suggesting potential adaptive exclusions to preserve leaf integrity under harsh environmental conditions.

label: Both
abstract: In a study of endophytic fungi in tropical legumes, root samples from Mimosa pudica were consistently colonized, whereas fungal endophytes were absent from leaf and stem tissues. This selective colonization pattern highlights the spatial variability in fungal endophyte-host interactions in legumes.

label: Absence
abstract: A comprehensive survey of fungal endophytes in Corylus avellana across multiple habitats yielded no detectable fungal presence in leaf, stem, or root tissues. High-throughput sequencing and culturing methods confirmed the absence of fungal DNA or viable isolates, suggesting that C. avellana may be naturally resistant to endophyte colonization.

label: Absence
abstract: Despite extensive sampling of Cucumis sativus plants in three distinct agricultural systems, no fungal endophytes were isolated from any tissues, including leaves, stems, roots, and flowers. Culturing on selective media and molecular analysis failed to detect fungal DNA, suggesting a true absence of endophytes in this species.

label: Absence
abstract: Endophytic fungi were not detected in any tissue of Triticum aestivum cultivated in sterile and non-sterile field conditions. Both culture-dependent methods and ITS sequencing yielded negative results, indicating that fungal endophytes are not universally present in wheat.

label: Absence
abstract: A study of endophytic fungi in native Nicotiana tabacum plants found no evidence of fungal colonization in leaves, stems, or roots. This absence persisted across all sampled populations, despite the use of diverse isolation techniques and DNA sequencing.

label: Absence
abstract: High-resolution metagenomics revealed no fungal endophyte DNA in Vicia faba plants grown under controlled greenhouse conditions. Culturing efforts similarly yielded no viable fungal colonies, suggesting that endophytes are not a component of the microbiome of this legume species.

label: Absence
abstract: An assessment of Beta vulgaris grown in saline soils revealed no fungal endophytes in any sampled tissues, including roots, stems, and leaves. DNA extraction and amplification consistently failed to produce ITS fungal sequences, supporting the conclusion of a complete absence of endophytes.

label: Absence
abstract: In a multi-year study of Helianthus tuberosus, no fungal endophytes were detected in any tissues, despite repeated sampling across multiple environmental conditions. These results challenge assumptions about the ubiquity of fungal endophytes in terrestrial plants.

label: Absence
abstract: Sampling of Avena sativa from organic and conventional fields showed no evidence of fungal endophyte colonization. Both traditional isolation techniques and next-generation sequencing confirmed the absence of fungal DNA in any tissues.

label: Absence
abstract: An investigation of fungal endophytes in Lactuca sativa leaves, stems, and roots across hydroponic and soil-based systems failed to detect any fungal presence. These findings suggest that L. sativa may lack the ecological or physiological compatibility necessary for endophyte colonization.

label: Absence
abstract: Comprehensive culturing and sequencing approaches failed to identify fungal endophytes in Capsicum annuum grown under field conditions. The absence of fungal colonization in roots, stems, and leaves suggests that C. annuum may not rely on endophytic associations for growth or resilience.

label: Absence
abstract: No fungal endophytes were detected in Rosa multiflora plants collected from urban and rural environments. Both ITS sequencing and culturing approaches yielded negative results, indicating an absence of endophytic fungi in this invasive species.

label: Absence
abstract: A systematic review of Daucus carota tissues revealed no fungal endophytes in roots, stems, or leaves, even under conditions designed to maximize fungal isolation. This lack of colonization suggests species-specific barriers to fungal endophyte establishment.

label: Absence
abstract: An investigation into Echinacea purpurea plants grown in sterile and natural soils found no evidence of fungal endophytes in any tissue. Culturing, DNA sequencing, and microscopy collectively supported the absence of fungal colonization.

label: Absence
abstract: Despite sampling Phaseolus vulgaris plants across a range of soil types, no fungal endophytes were found in any tissues. These results challenge the assumption that endophytes are universally present in legumes.

label: Absence
abstract: Endophytic fungi were not detected in Brassica oleracea leaves, stems, or roots grown in field trials. Isolation techniques and metagenomic sequencing consistently failed to identify fungal presence, confirming the absence of fungal endophytes in this crop species.

label: Absence
abstract: A study on Picea abies seedlings grown in natural forests and experimental greenhouses revealed no detectable fungal endophytes in needles, stems, or roots. These findings suggest that endophytic colonization may not occur in all coniferous plants.

label: Absence
abstract: Extensive sampling of Zea mays across diverse agricultural systems revealed no evidence of fungal endophyte colonization in roots, stems, or leaves. Both culturing and DNA-based methods confirmed the absence of fungal endophytes in this crop.

label: Absence
abstract: Despite repeated attempts, no fungal endophytes were isolated from Citrullus lanatus plants grown under field or greenhouse conditions. PCR analysis of root, stem, and leaf tissues confirmed the absence of fungal DNA, suggesting that C. lanatus is not a host for endophytes.

label: Absence
abstract: A study of Sorbus aucuparia in temperate forests failed to detect fungal endophytes in any sampled tissues. Sequencing and culture-based approaches yielded no positive results, indicating that fungal endophytes are not present in this tree species.

label: Absence
abstract: In a survey of Rubus idaeus, no fungal endophytes were detected in leaves, stems, or roots across three distinct geographic locations. Culturing and molecular analysis confirmed the absence of fungal DNA, highlighting the possibility of endophyte-free species in the Rosaceae family.

label: Review
abstract: Fungal endophytes are recognized for their roles in enhancing plant growth, stress resistance, and pathogen defense. However, recent studies have reported instances where fungal endophytes are notably absent in some plant species or tissues, challenging assumptions of their ubiquity. This review synthesizes evidence on the absence of fungal endophytes in specific taxa and ecosystems, exploring potential barriers to colonization, including host-specific chemical defenses, environmental conditions, and evolutionary dynamics. The implications of these findings are discussed in the context of plant-microbe interactions and ecosystem functioning.

label: Review
abstract: Endophytic fungi have been studied extensively for their diverse roles in plant health and ecology, yet gaps remain in understanding their absence in certain plants and environments. This review examines global studies reporting the lack of fungal endophytes in particular host plants, focusing on methodological limitations, ecological influences, and plant traits that may inhibit fungal colonization. Additionally, we discuss the evolutionary implications of endophyte absence and its impact on plant-microbe networks.

label: Review
abstract: This review explores the ecological and physiological factors underlying the absence of fungal endophytes in some plants. Analyzing over 200 studies, we identify patterns in plant species, tissue types, and environmental conditions where fungal endophytes are consistently absent. We propose a framework to classify plants based on their compatibility with endophytes and highlight research priorities to address the mechanisms behind these absences.

label: Review
abstract: Although fungal endophytes are often considered ubiquitous, this review highlights cases where they are absent, either completely or in specific tissues or environments. By synthesizing studies from agriculture, forestry, and natural ecosystems, we investigate the role of host traits, climate, and microbial competition in shaping endophyte distributions. The review also examines the implications of endophyte absence for plant health and resilience in changing climates.

label: Review
abstract: The global distribution of fungal endophytes is uneven, with several studies reporting their absence in particular plant species and ecosystems. This review consolidates evidence on endophyte absence, examining the potential ecological, genetic, and biochemical barriers to colonization. We also discuss the broader implications for understanding plant-microbe interactions and the evolution of symbiotic relationships.

label: Review
abstract: This comprehensive review examines the factors contributing to the absence of fungal endophytes in certain plant species. We assess the roles of host specificity, tissue type, environmental conditions, and plant biochemistry in determining endophyte presence or absence. Special attention is given to studies that challenge the paradigm of universal endophyte presence, providing a nuanced understanding of plant-fungus interactions.

label: Review
abstract: Fungal endophytes are widely recognized for their ecological significance, yet their absence in some plants remains poorly understood. This review synthesizes evidence from studies where endophytes were not detected, examining methodological considerations, environmental influences, and host traits. We discuss the implications of these findings for agricultural systems and natural ecosystems, proposing directions for future research.

label: Review
abstract: The absence of fungal endophytes in certain plant species and tissues poses intriguing questions about plant-fungus interactions. This review synthesizes evidence from studies reporting endophyte absence, focusing on methodological rigor, ecological drivers, and host resistance mechanisms. The review also considers the evolutionary context of endophyte absence and its potential implications for plant adaptation.

label: Review
abstract: Fungal endophytes are often regarded as ubiquitous symbionts, yet their absence in some systems challenges this notion. This review critically examines the literature on endophyte absence, addressing factors such as host-specific antifungal compounds, ecological constraints, and methodological limitations. The review highlights case studies where plants lack endophytes and discusses their implications for understanding symbiosis.

label: Review
abstract: Endophytic fungi have been a focus of ecological and agricultural research, but reports of their absence in specific plants are less understood. This review examines the evidence for endophyte absence, synthesizing data from diverse ecosystems and host species. We explore the roles of plant defenses, habitat conditions, and symbiotic competition in shaping these patterns and their implications for plant health.

label: Review
abstract: Fungal endophytes are a rich source of bioactive compounds with significant potential for medicinal applications. This review synthesizes current knowledge on secondary metabolites produced by endophytic fungi, highlighting their roles in antimicrobial, anticancer, anti-inflammatory, and antiviral activities. Special attention is given to breakthroughs in endophyte-derived drugs, such as taxol and other pharmaceuticals. We discuss advancements in genome mining and metabolomics that have accelerated the discovery of novel compounds, as well as challenges in large-scale production and commercialization.

label: Review
abstract: The global distribution of fungal endophytes reflects a complex interplay between host plants, environmental factors, and microbial interactions. This review examines patterns of endophyte diversity and composition across biomes, focusing on key drivers such as climate, soil type, and host phylogeny. We also address gaps in geographic and taxonomic sampling, proposing strategies for uncovering the full extent of endophyte biodiversity. The review concludes with insights into how global environmental changes, including deforestation and climate change, may reshape endophyte distributions.

label: Review
abstract: Fungal endophytes have emerged as important players in agriculture, offering potential solutions for enhancing crop productivity and resilience. This review explores their roles in plant growth promotion, pathogen suppression, and stress tolerance. We evaluate recent advances in harnessing endophytes for sustainable agriculture, including inoculant development and field applications. Challenges such as host specificity, strain stability, and regulatory hurdles are discussed alongside prospects for integrating endophytes into climate-resilient farming systems.

label: Review
abstract: The ecological roles of fungal endophytes extend beyond their host plants, influencing community dynamics and ecosystem processes. This review synthesizes research on the contributions of endophytes to nutrient cycling, herbivory resistance, and plant community structure. We explore how endophytes mediate interactions between plants and other organisms, including herbivores, pathogens, and mutualists. Emerging insights into the context-dependence of these interactions are discussed, providing a framework for understanding the multifunctionality of endophytes in ecosystems.

label: Review
abstract: This review provides a comprehensive overview of the evolutionary relationships between fungal endophytes and their host plants. We examine evidence for co-evolutionary patterns, exploring how endophytes have adapted to diverse plant lineages and ecological niches. The roles of horizontal gene transfer, host specificity, and environmental pressures in shaping these relationships are highlighted. The review also discusses the implications of endophyte evolution for understanding symbiosis and microbial diversity.

label: Review
abstract: Endophytic fungi are a promising source of biotechnological innovations, particularly in the development of bioactive compounds and sustainable materials. This review surveys recent advances in bioprospecting fungal endophytes for industrial applications, including pharmaceuticals, biofuels, and biodegradable polymers. We discuss the technological tools driving this field, such as genome editing and synthetic biology, and address challenges in scaling up endophyte-based production systems.

label: Review
abstract: The role of fungal endophytes in mediating plant responses to climate change is an emerging area of research. This review explores how endophytes influence plant resilience to drought, heat, and other abiotic stresses. We synthesize studies examining the mechanisms underlying these interactions, including hormonal signaling, nutrient acquisition, and oxidative stress mitigation. The review also considers how shifts in endophyte communities due to climate change may affect ecosystem stability and plant adaptation.

label: Review
abstract: Fungal endophytes have shown potential as tools for bioremediation in polluted environments. This review highlights studies demonstrating the capacity of endophytes to degrade organic pollutants, tolerate heavy metals, and improve plant growth in contaminated soils. We explore the mechanisms by which endophytes enhance phytoremediation efficiency, including symbiotic stress alleviation and pollutant transformation. The challenges and opportunities of integrating endophytes into large-scale remediation efforts are also discussed.

label: Review
abstract: Endophytic fungi exhibit diverse lifestyles and interactions with their host plants, ranging from mutualism to latent pathogenicity. This review examines the factors that determine the nature of these interactions, including host genotype, endophyte identity, and environmental conditions. We propose a continuum model of endophyte-host relationships, highlighting the dynamic nature of these interactions and their implications for plant fitness and ecosystem processes.

label: Review
abstract: The discovery of fungal endophytes has significantly expanded our understanding of microbial biodiversity. This review provides a historical perspective on endophyte research, tracing key milestones in their study from early observations to the advent of high-throughput sequencing. We discuss how methodological innovations, such as metagenomics and metabolomics, have transformed the field, uncovering the immense diversity and functional roles of endophytes. Future directions for integrating endophyte research with other disciplines, such as microbiome science and synthetic ecology, are outlined.

label: Presence
abstract: DgCr22.1b, an endophytic isolate of Talaromyces sp., was collected in the Amazonian Rainforest from the medicinal plant Duguetia stelechantha. From the fractionation of the methanolic mycelial extract, a new xanthone dimer talaroxanthone was isolated. The structure of this new compound was elucidated based on spectroscopic analyses including 2D nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) experiments.
authors: Koolen, HHF; Menezes, LS; Souza, MP; Silva, FMA; Almeida, FGO; de Souza, AQL; Nepel, A; Barison, A; da Silva, FH; Evangelista, DE; de Souza, ADL

label: Presence
abstract: Fungal endophytes do not harm the plant when they live inside the host. Previous studies also showed that the content of some secondary metabolites are correlated to the endophytes within plant. Whether such a mutualistic symbiosis system could be implanted to bio-engineering or not will be an important and exciting problem. Here a fungal endophyte was co-cultured with the cell suspension of Acer ginnnala which is rich in gallich acid to test the problem above. The results showed that the growth of plant cells and the cell vitality decreased after the endophyte added, while gallic acid content increased. It was preliminarily determined that there is a partial competition relationship.
authors: Qi, FH; Zhan, YG; Zeng, FS; Jing, TZ
author_full_names: Qi, Fenghui; Zhan, Yaguang; Zeng, Fansuo; Jing, Tianzhong
article_title: Effect of Endophytic Fungi on the Growth Situation in Cell Suspension Cultures of Acer Ginnala Maxim
source_title: MATERIALS FOR ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AND ENERGY APPLICATION, PTS 1 AND 2

label: Presence
abstract: Fungal endophytes of the genus Acremonium infect many grass species. They exist in the intercellular spaces of the aerial plant parts, most abundantly in the leaf sheaths. They therefore must obtain all of their nutrients from the apoplastic spaces in the plant. This report is the first comprehensive, biochemically based study of sugar uptake by Acremonium spp. The endophytes (Acremonium typhinum) were isolated from Festuca rubra plants and were grown in culture. Individual colonies were incubated in the presence of [U-C-14] radiolabeled glucose, fructose, or sucrose for 20 minutes and the uptake quantified by scintillation counting. The uptake rates for all three sugars were biphasic, indicating two distinct mechanisms of transport. At low sugar concentrations (below 10 mM) the uptake was saturable and had the characteristics of a carrier-mediated mechanism. At high sugar concentrations (10-100 mM) the uptake was linear suggesting diffusion as the predominant mechanism of uptake. From competition experiments (uptake of labeled sugar in the presence of a different unlabeled sugar) it appeared that there were separate carriers for glucose and fructose. Two mechanisms for sucrose uptake were detected, a sucrose carrier and hexose uptake as a result of cell wall invertase. Cell wall invertase activity of the fungal isolates was inducible by growing the fungi on sucrose containing media.
authors: LAM, CK; BELANGER, FC; WHITE, JF; DAIE, J
author_full_names: LAM, CK; BELANGER, FC; WHITE, JF; DAIE, J
article_title: MECHANISM AND RATE OF SUGAR UPTAKE BY ACREMONIUM-TYPHINUM, AN ENDOPHYTIC FUNGUS INFECTING FESTUCA-RUBRA - EVIDENCE FOR PRESENCE OF A CELL-WALL INVERTASE IN ENDOPHYTIC FUNGI

label: Presence
abstract: Many plant endophytes produce mycotoxins, but how host genetic variation influences endophyte colonization and mycotoxin production under natural conditions is poorly understood. This interaction has not been fully considered in many previous studies which used controlled experiments with agronomic or model plant species. Here, we investigated this interaction in a naturally occurring forb (a locoweed species) Oxytropis ochrocephala, its symbiotic endophyte Alternaria oxytropis, and the mycotoxin swainsonine. Host genetic variation was characterized by microsatellite markers. Endophyte infection rate and swainsonine levels were determined by PCR and HPLC, respectively. Genetic markers defined two distinct host populations and revealed that host genetics were significantly correlated with geographical location, elevation, and precipitation. As the host diverged, symbiotic interactions were reduced or failed to produce detectable swainsonine in one host population. Host genotype and precipitation had a significant impact in shaping swainsonine production at the population level. This study highlights the effect of host genotype in influencing this interaction in locoweeds.
authors: He, W; Guo, LW; Wang, L; Zhao, QQ; Guo, LZ; Cao, W; Mur, LAJ; Wei, YH

article_title: Host Genotype and Precipitation Influence of Fungal Endophyte Symbiosis and Mycotoxin Abundance in a Locoweed

label: Presence
abstract: Microbial plant symbionts are widely spread in nature changing the way their hosts interact with their environment. Neotyphodium fungal endophytes (Clavicipitaceae) are grass symbionts known by their production of alkaloids, toxic for herbivores. Here, we hypothesized that endophytes confer associational protection to non-host plants and change emission of host volatile-compounds. In an outdoor mesocosm experiment, we examined aphid infestation on Trifolium repens plants, in response to Neotyphodium occultans presence in neighbouring Lolium multiflorum. Contrasting levels of Rhizobium were generated in T. repens plants considering that symbiosis with N-2-fixers would influence herbivore abundance. Aphid infestation increased responding to symbiotic status of T. repens plants, when surrounded by non-symbiotic L. multiflorum plants. Endophytes modified the volatile imprints of L. multiflorum plants measured by an electronic nose, suggesting a potential mechanism to benefit neighbours. This associational protection constitutes a new mutualism trait of grass-endophyte symbiosis, becoming a non-private benefit available to other community partners. authors: Parisi, PAG; Grimoldi, AA; Omacini, M
author_full_names: Garcia Parisi, P. A.; Grimoldi, A. A.; Omacini, M.
article_title: Endophytic fungi of grasses protect other plants from aphid herbivory
orci_ds: Garcia-Parisi, Pablo Adrian/0000-0001-7725-9553; Grimoldi, Agustin Alberto/0000-0001-7075-1879; Omacini, Marina/0000-0003-1460-262X

label: Presence
abstract: Morphological and physiological responses to water deficit of two tall fescue (Festuca arundinacea) cultivars were compared in a glasshouse experiment and the effect, on those responses, of artificial infection of the tall fescue plants with two fungal endophyte (Neotyphodium coenophialum) strains was evaluated. The cultivars were Maris Kasba (MK), of Mediterranean origin, and El Palenque (EP), an Argentinian cultivar of temperate origin. The endophyte strains AgResearch isolate (AR501) and the Kentucky (KY31) wild type were compared with nil-endophyte controls. Leaf growth rare of EP plants under water deficit was higher and leaf senescence rate lower than for MK plants (P < 0.05). MK plants showed a greater increase in the proportion of dead leaf tissue than EP plants as water deficit increased (P < 0.05). Stomatal conductance and lamina osmotic adjustment at low soil moisture were lower for MK than EP (P < 0.05). Endophyte-infected plants had a lower dry weight and tiller number, but a higher net growth rate during water deficit treatments than endophyte-free plants (P < 0.05). A significant cultivar x endophyte interaction (P < 0.05) was observed for many variables studied. This implies that any new endophyte strain should be evaluated in combination with the plant genotypes with which it is likely to be associated in commercial practice. MK-KY31 and EP-AR501 associations appeared to tolerate short-term water deficit more effectively than other associations studied. There was evidence that the two endophyte strains studied had different physiological effects on their tall fescue host plants.
authors: Assuero, SG; Matthew, C; Kemp, PD; Latch, GCM; Barker, DJ; Haslett, SJ

article_title: Morphological and physiological effects of water deficit and endophyte infection on contrasting tall fescue cultivars

label: Presence
abstract: Most plants obtain nitrogen through nitrogen-fixing bacteria and microbial decomposition of plant and animal material. Many vascular plants are able to form close symbiotic associations with endophytic fungi. Metarhizium is a common plant endophyte found in a large number of ecosystems. This abundant soil fungus is also a pathogen to a large number of insects, which are a source of nitrogen. It is possible that the endophytic capability and insect pathogenicity of Metarhizium are coupled to provide an active method of nitrogen transfer to plant hosts via fungal mycelia. We used soil microcosms to test the ability of M. robertsii to translocate insect-derived nitrogen to plants. Insects were injected with N-15-labeled nitrogen, and we tracked the incorporation of N-15 into amino acids in two plant species, haricot bean (Phaseolus vulgaris) and switchgrass (Panicum virgatum), in the presence of M. robertsii. These findings are evidence that active nitrogen acquisition by plants in this tripartite interaction may play a larger role in soil nitrogen cycling than previously thought.
authors: Behie, SW; Zelisko, PM; Bidochka, MJ
author_full_names: Behie, S. W.; Zelisko, P. M.; Bidochka, M. J.
article_title: Endophytic Insect-Parasitic Fungi Translocate Nitrogen Directly from Insects to Plants

label: Presence
abstract: Phyllosticta is a cosmopolitan group of fungi found on various host plants, occurring as pathogens, endophytes and saprobes. Diseases caused by Phyllosticta commonly include leaf and fruit spots that can affect economically important plants. The genus is characterized mainly by aseptate and hyaline conidia and ascospores. Its conidia are surrounded by a mucilaginous sheath, with a single mucoid apical appendage while ascospores exhibit a mucoid cap at both ends. Given that many Phyllosticta taxa are cryptic and share similar morphologies, it is arduous to depict taxonomically relevant characters solely on the basis of morphological or ecological features. Coupled with morphological description, multi -locus phylogenetic analyses of species comprising complexes are used to broadly describe this genus and understand species boundaries. Despite several published taxonomic revisions and enumerations of Phyllosticta species, there is still considerable confusion when identifying these taxa. Herein, we establish three new host records for P. capitalensis, and one new geographical record for P. musaechinensis in Thailand, and one new host and geographical record for P. citribrasiliensis in Russia. We provide an updated phylogenetic tree based on several gene markers: ITS, LSU, ACT, GAPDH, RPB2, and TEF-1 alpha. This includes all Phyllosticta species for which sequence data is available. Six individual Phyllosticta species complexes are accepted. In addition, we synonymize P. ericarum with P. citribrasiliensis.

label: Presence
abstract: Recent work on microbiomes is revealing the wealth and importance of plant-microbe interactions. Microbial symbionts are proposed to have profound effects on fitness of their host plants and vice versa, especially when their fitness is tightly linked. Here we studied local adaptation of host plants and possible fitness contribution of such symbiosis in the context of abiotic environmental factors. We conducted a four-way multi-year reciprocal transplant experiment with natural populations of the perennial grass Festuca rubra s.l. from northern and southern Finland, Faroe Islands and Spain. We included F. rubra with and without transmitted symbiotic fungus Epichloe that is vertically transmitted via host seed. We found local adaptation across the European range, as evidenced by higher host fitness of the local geographic origin compared with nonlocals at three of the four studied sites, suggesting that selection pressures are driving evolution in different directions. Abiotic factors did not result in strong fitness effects related to Epichloe symbiosis, indicating that other factors such as herbivory are more likely to contribute to fitness differences between plants naturally occurring with or without Epichloe. Nevertheless, in the case of asymmetric symbiosis that is obligatory for the symbiont, abiotic conditions that affect performance of the host, may also cause selective pressure for the symbiont.

label: Presence
abstract: The aim of this work was to study the fungal diversity in Paspalum notatum, in order to determine the potential biological control of disease-causing pathogens and their effects on growth promotion. Two isolates of Cercospora dianellicola were identified from asymptomatic P. notatum leaves, as an endophytic species. The possible benefits for the host plant remain to be analyzed.

label: Presence
abstract: The fungal diversity in harvested apples from organic or conventional management practices was analyzed in different fruit locations (stem end, calyx end, peel, and wounded flesh) shortly after fruit purchase (T1) and after 2 weeks of storage (T5). A total of 5,760,162 high-quality fungal sequences were recovered and assigned to 8,504 Operational Taxonomic Units. Members of the phylum Ascomycota were dominant in all samples and accounted for 91.6% of the total number of detected sequences. This was followed by Basidiomycota (8%), Chytridiomycota (0.1%), and unidentified fungi (0.3%). Alpha and beta diversity analyses revealed the presence of significantly different fungal populations in the investigated fruit parts. Among detected fungi, the genus Penicillium prevailed in the peel and in the wounded flesh while Alternaria spp. prevailed in the calyx and stem end samples that included apple core tissues. Several taxonomic units that appear to be closely related to pathogenic fungi associated with secondary human infections were present in peel and wounds. Moreover, significantly different populations were revealed in organic and conventional apples and this result was consistent in all investigated fruit parts (calyx end, peel, stem end, and wounded flesh). Several unique taxa were exclusively detected in organic apples suggesting that management practices may have been a contributing factor in determining the taxa present. In contrast, little differences were revealed in the two assessment times (T1 and T5). Results of the present study represent an advancement of the current knowledge on the fungal microbiota in collected fruit tissues of apple.

label: Presence
abstract: The present study discusses the frequency distribution and genetic diversity of novel fungal endopyte Alternaria alternata within the Pongammia pinnata plant samples. A total of ten plant samples of Pongammia pinnata, Pierre. (Karanja) were collected from specific locations of Sanganer region of Rajasthan for the isolation of fungal endophytes. Of these, maximum frequency of Alternaria alternata (22.29%) were recorded which are morphologically similar but ecologically variant. Efficacy of randomly amplified polymorphic DNA (RAPD), were assessed in seventeen individuals of the primers was GCC 180 where as 10 bands were generated by GCC 181. The similarity coefficient matrix generated for the primers was subjected to algorithm UPGMA (Unweighted Pair Group Method Analysis) and clusters were generated using NTSYS 2.02 pc program. To stabilize the level of relatedness among the seventeen ecologically variant Alternaria alternata accessions, the dendrogram was constructed, which showed that all the isolates were diversified endophytically with in the plant Pongamia pinnata. © 2013 Asian Network for Scientific Information.
article_title: Frequency distribution and assessment of genetic diversity of novel endophyte Alternaria alternata accessions isolated from Pongamia pinnata L

label: Presence
abstract: Understanding how species-rich communities persist is a foundational question in ecology. In tropical forests, tree diversity is structured by edaphic factors, climate, and biotic interactions, with seasonality playing an essential role at landscape scales: wetter and less seasonal forests typically harbor higher tree diversity than more seasonal forests. We posited that the abiotic factors shaping tree diversity extend to hyperdiverse symbionts in leaves-fungal endophytes-that influence plant health, function, and resilience to stress. Through surveys in forests across Panama that considered climate, seasonality, and covarying biotic factors, we demonstrate that endophyte richness varies negatively with temperature seasonality. Endophyte community structure and taxonomic composition reflect both temperature seasonality and climate (mean annual temperature and precipitation). Overall our findings highlight the vital role of climate-related factors in shaping the hyperdiversity of these important and little-known symbionts of the trees that, in turn, form the foundations of tropical forest biodiversity.

label: Other
abstract: A manipulative field study was carried out to determine whether the foliar endophyte fungus, Phialocephala scopiformis DAOM 229536, decreased the performance of eastern spruce budworm, Choristoneura fumiferana larvae developing on white spruce trees. Overwintered second-instar budworm larvae from a laboratory colony or from a wild population were placed on endophyte positive or negative trees one or two weeks before budburst. The presence of the endophyte in the needles reduced the survival of C. fumiferana from both a wild population and a laboratory colony. Survival for budworm juveniles up to pupation and to adult emergence was 13% and 17% lower, respectively, on endophyte positive trees. The endophyte did not influence the size or sex of survivors and budworm survival was not influenced by any two- or three-way interactions. Budworm survival was higher for wild than for laboratory-reared budworm and for budworm placed on trees a week before budburst. This may be the first field study to demonstrate the efficacy of an endophytic fungus against wild individuals of a major forest insect pest. The efficacy of the endophyte at low larval densities suggests that it could be a useful tactic to limit spruce budworm population growth in the context of an early intervention strategy.

label: Other
abstract: A recent paper by Rasmussen et al., (New Phytol 2007; 173:787-97) describes the interactions between Lolium perenne cultivars with contrasting carbohydrate content and the symbiotic fungal endophyte Neotyphodium lolii at different levels of nitrogen supply. In a subsequent study undertaken by Rasmussen et al., (Plant Physiol 2008; 146:1440-53) 66 metabolic variables were analysed in the same material, revealing widespread effects of endophyte infection, N supply and cultivar carbohydrate content on both primary and secondary metabolites. Here, we link insect numerical responses to these metabolic responses using multiple regression analysis. ©2008 Landes Bioscience.

label: Other
abstract: Tea (Camellia sinensis) and coffee (Coffea arabica) are the most consumed infusion beverages in the world. Each agroecosystem for their productions comes with a rich complex of insect and mite associates, most of which are not regarded as pests. However, a significant number of serious pests attack the leaves, roots, stems, and roots of each crop. The foliage of tea, the marketable part of the plant, is attacked by tortricid moths, hemipterans, and coleopterans. Although Bacillus thuringiensis is the most used microbial control agent of lepidopteran pests of tea, considerable research has been conducted on entomopathogenic viruses, mostly Baculoviruses, for their control and entomopathogenic fungi (EPF) as microbial control agents of hemipteran pests. Coffee plants are attacked by a broad range of insect and mite pests including coleopterans, lepidopterans, hemipterans, and mites. Among these, the coffee berry borer (CBB) is the most economically important pest of coffee worldwide. The EPF, Beauveria bassiana, has been used along with other interventions for its control in Colombia. Exploitation of the endophytic fungi associated with coffee as possible control agents of CBB is discussed. © 2017 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
article_title: Microbial Control of Insect Pests of Tea and Coffee
source_title: Microbial Control of Insect and Mite Pests: From Theory to Practice

label: Other
abstract: The component composition and content of mycotoxins in the terrestrial parts of perennial legumes of the genera Medicago (M. falcata L., M. lupulina L., M. sativa L.), Melilotus (M. albus Medik., M. officinalis (L.) Pall.), as well as Caucasian goat's rue (Galega orientalis Lam.), Spanish licorice (Glycyrrhiza glabra L.), and Washington lupine (Lupinus polyphyllus Lindl.) selected from natural biocenoses within different periods of vegetation, were studied. The intensity of accumulation and the variety of fungal metabolites are most clearly expressed in licorice and lupine and more weakly expressed in goat's rue; the species of alfalfa and melilot, the contamination of which did not differ noticeably, occupied an intermediate position. The general features and peculiarities of the mycotoxin profile during the period of vegetation in the plants of the genera Medicago and Melilotus are discussed.
author_full_names: Burkin, A. A.; Kononenko, G. P.
article_title: Secondary Metabolites of Micromycetes in Plants of the Family Fabaceae Genera Galega, Glycyrrhiza, Lupinus, Medicago, and Melilotus

label: Both
abstract: Cool-season grasses establish symbioses with vertically transmitted Neotyphodium endophytes widespread in nature. The frequency of endophyte-infected plants in closed populations (i.e., without migrations) depends on both the differential fitness between infected and non-infected plants, and the endophyte-transmission efficiency. Most studies have been focused on the first mechanism ignoring the second. Infection frequency and endophyte transmission from vegetative tissues to seeds were surveyed in two grasses growing in vegetation units that differ in flood and grazing regimes, and soil salinity. Transmission efficiency and infection frequency for tall fescue did not vary significantly and were 0.98 and 1.00, respectively. For Italian ryegrass, transmission efficiency and infection frequency were 0.88 and 0.57 in humid prairies, and 0.96 and 0.96 in the other vegetation units. Only in humid mesophytic meadows, the observed pattern was irrespective of the presence or absence of grazers. Our results suggest that selection forces for endophyte infection are different for both species. Imperfect transmission was only compensated in tall fescue through an increased fitness of infected plants. Interpreting variations of infection frequency only in terms of differential fitness can be misleading, considering that endophyte transmission can be imperfect and variable in nature. Therefore, this study highlights the importance of measuring transmission efficiency.
authors: Gundel, PE; Garibaldi, LA; Tognetti, PM; Aragón, R; Ghersa, CM; Omacini, M
author_full_names: Gundel, Pedro E.; Garibaldi, Lucas A.; Tognetti, Pedro M.; Aragon, Roxana; Ghersa, Claudio M.; Omacini, Marina
article_title: Imperfect Vertical Transmission of the Endophyte Neotyphodium in Exotic Grasses in Grasslands of the Flooding Pampa
researcher_ids: Tognetti, Pedro/AAF-7018-2019; Gundel, Pedro/A-5314-2013; Garibaldi, Lucas/D-7302-2013
orci_ds: Garibaldi, Lucas Alejandro/0000-0003-0725-4049; Gundel, Pedro Emilio/0000-0003-3246-0282; Tognetti, Pedro M./0000-0001-7358-1334; Omacini, Marina/0000-0003-1460-262X

label: Both
abstract: Levels of the endophytic fungus (Acremonium coenophialum) were determined in samples of tall fescue (Festuca arundinacaea) plants and seed over a 3-yr period. The mean infection of plant samples from 26 states was 58%; however, seed samples were less infected (54%), particularly when live endophyte was assayed (6%). The cultivar KY-31 was most heavily infected, although endophyte-free seed of this and other cultivars were common. Livestock owners reporting symptoms of fescue toxicity also reported higher levels of infection than owners not observing symptoms.
article_title: INCIDENCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF THE TALL FESCUE ENDOPHYTE IN THE UNITED-STATES

label: Both
abstract: Pooideae grasses may be colonized by systemic fungal endophytes. The fitness of endophyte depends entirely on resources and seed transmission from the host plant, while colonized plants may gain increased survival, growth, and reproduction relative to their uncolonized conspecifics. Most research of endophyte-grass interactions have been carried out on few cultivars of tall fescue (Schedonorus phoenix) and their symbiont Neotyphodium coenophialum. Lack of studies using wild populations of tall fescue across the species natural distribution range, however, limits the understanding of the ecological and evolutionary role of the symbiosis in nature. We performed a common garden experiment in Southern Finland with three wild, tall fescue populations from northern Europe and the forage cultivar Kentucky-31 (KY-31). For each population, we used naturally endophyte-colonized, naturally endophyte-colonized but endophyte removed (decolonized), and naturally uncolonized plants to separate effects due to the host genotype from the endophyte. We evaluated growth variables and survival in four environmental treatments of varying water and nutrients. Supply of water and nutrients increased plant biomass and reproductive effort in all populations. This effect was higher for KY-31 plants which produced on average 55 % more seeds than wild plants, indicating better adaptation to high resource environments. However, the higher incidence of Claviceps sp. and the low winter survival indicated KY-31 tall fescue is mal-adapted to Northern European conditions. Naturally colonized plants had greater plant biomass (a parts per thousand 12 %), reproductive effort (a parts per thousand 22 %) and seed mass (a parts per thousand 29 %) than naturally uncolonized and decolonized plants. Nonetheless, endophyte colonization did not affect plant survival, and the effects of endophyte colonization on tiller number, panicle/tiller ratio and Claviceps sp. incidence depended on the population origin. In the wild populations, endophyte removal only reduced the number of tillers (a parts per thousand 29 % lower), while the difference between naturally colonized and naturally uncolonized plants was not significant. Our results show that endophyte symbiont increases tall fescue performance in general, but the differences between wild populations and cultivars indicate adaptation to local habitats and agronomic management, respectively. The comparison of naturally endophyte-colonized and decolonized plants suggests certain plant genotype-endophyte combinations found within populations result from local selection pressures.
authors: Gundel, PE; Helander, M; Casas, C; Hamilton, CE; Faeth, SH; Saikkonen, K
author_full_names: Gundel, Pedro E.; Helander, Marjo; Casas, Cecilia; Hamilton, Cyd E.; Faeth, Stanley H.; Saikkonen, Kari
article_title: Neotyphodium fungal endophyte in tall fescue (Schedonorus phoenix): a comparison of three Northern European wild populations and the cultivar Kentuky-31

label: Review
abstract: This chapter summarises research carried out on the biology, ecology and the impact of the holomorph Apiognonwnia quercina/Discula quercina in oak forests. The major life-history traits and aspects of the epidemiology (isolation, survival, reproduction, dispersal, host selectivity) and control of the oak anthracnose agent are elucidated. The role of weather patterns in disrupting the delicate interaction between the host tree and the microorganism is outlined. The evidence suggests that changes in the climate profoundly alter the plant-endophyte symbiosis, generating conflicts of interest between the partners in the interaction. When such competing interests arise, the survival and reproduction of one member of the interaction do not conform with that of the partner. The interaction becomes thus disadvantageous and harmful to one of the organisms and the symbiosis from mutualistic or neutral turns antagonistic. The fungal partner, which under normal conditions survives in quiescence, with a low biomass, resumes growth but now switches from a latent, asymptomatic occupier of inner oak tissues to an aggressive coloniser that sporulates profusely over the tree surface. The importance of investigating the functioning and the role of the plant-endophyte symbiosis in perennial host trees in natural forests is stressed.
article_title: The Holomorph Apiognomonia quercina/Discula quercina as a Pathogen/Endophyte in Oak
source_title: ENDOPHYTES OF FOREST TREE: BIOLOGY AND APPLICATIONS
